text:
Fallen leaves whisper
memories of hands once held
autumn does not wait

You said you'd return
The tea has long gone cold now
but I still pour two

In a dream, we danced
your laughter broke through the dark
like a bell at dawn

Raindrops on the sill
each one a soft I miss you
echoing the storm

The moon stays silent
watching lovers drift apart
on tides of regret

Snow covers the path—
I no longer know the way
back to who I was.

A cracked photograph
smiles from another lifetime—
dust softens the truth.

Wind through empty swings—
the playground remembers us
better than I do.

We spoke with our eyes,
too afraid to break the peace
with what we both knew.

Grief is not a storm—
it's a slow and quiet tide
pulling you under.

Cherry blossoms fall—
each one a goodbye we said
without knowing it.

She hums through the walls—
a song I don't recognize
but somehow still mourn.

The stars don't answer,
but I still ask them questions
just to feel heard.

Beneath all the noise,
there is a silence shaped like
the sound of your name.

Hands once meant for mine
now hold umbrellas for two
in another spring.

The light in your room
flickers like the way you spoke—
never quite certain.

I water the plants
you forgot to take with you—
they still lean your way.

Night folds in softly,
as if trying to protect
what I dreamed of you.

Your voice in the wind—
not the words, but the silence
between what you said.

A train in the dusk,
carrying strangers and thoughts
I will never know.

The clock ticks gently—
I measure time in heartbeats
since you walked away.

We laughed in the rain.
Now, every storm feels like you—
warm, and then you're gone.

Your old sweater hangs
where I pretend not to look—
threadbare with waiting.

I write you a note
and fold it into the breeze—
hoping it finds you.

Evening sky burns red.
I don't ask what it means now—
some things are just gone.

Mist curls through the pines,
touching every branch like breath—
morning's quiet prayer.

A single crow calls
into the wide open blue—
even clouds listen.

River after rain,
stones glisten like fallen stars
beneath rushing light.

The moon climbs slowly,
threading through the drifting clouds
like a needle's pull.

Beneath the oak tree,
moss grows where no one has stepped—
time forgets us here.

Sunflowers all turn
toward a sky that won't speak—
faith without a word.

Cicadas erupt—
a choir of heat and longing
rising from the dust.

Frost on the window—
its lacework fading too fast
for me to admire.

A fox in the snow
leaves behind a quiet path—
no sound but my breath.

The sea meets the shore,
speaking in a thousand tongues
but saying one thing.

Rain begins to fall—
each drop writes a soft story
on the thirsty earth.

Lightning splits the sky,
a silent breath held between
what was and will be.

A deer lifts its head—
for a moment, the whole world
forgets how to move.

The wind bends the grass,
not to break it, but to teach
the art of staying.

Fog clings to the hills,
as if even the mountains
long to be hidden.

Crickets call at dusk—
a language of warmth and dark
only night can hear.

Leaves drift through the air,
each one dancing toward rest
with no need to rush.

Icicles forming—
even silence can sharpen
when the world holds still.

Petals on the stream,
carried past roots and river—
beauty without end.

The stars blink awake—
not all light comes with thunder,
some just quietly.

Snow falls without sound—
the world forgets its own name
under a white hush.

Frost blooms on the glass,
a garden of cold silence
grown in a night's breath.

Footprints in the snow—
tiny stories written fast,
gone by morning light.

The lake does not move.
Ice holds even the moonlight
like a buried thought.

Winter sun appears,
too tired to melt the frost—
still, it tries again.

A branch cracks with weight—
winter takes what cannot bend
without asking why.

Clouds hang low and gray,
their bellies full of snowflakes
not yet brave enough.

Chimney smoke rises,
twirling like old lullabies
into the pale dusk.

Cold air bites the skin—
yet inside, the kettle sings
like nothing has changed.

Breath ghosts in moonlight,
a fleeting warmth in the dark
trying to hold on.

Blankets pile like snow,
your hand resting over mine—
the storm can wait now.

Steam fogs up the glass,
a kettle hums in the back—
every sound is home.

Candles flicker low,
a hush warmed by cinnamon
and your gentle laugh.

Wool socks, firelight glow—
a dog sighs beside the hearth,
dreaming of dry fields.

The snow taps softly,
and I make tea for two cups—
even if you're gone.

A shared bowl of stew,
footsteps wet by the doorway—
each return matters.

Books stacked by the bed,
a scarf hung over the chair—
everything in place.

Hot chocolate clings close
to the rim of a chipped mug—
comfort isn't new.

Outside, all is ice,
but inside, bread and laughter
rise in quiet loops.

You sleep next to me,
and though the cold gnaws the roof,
I forget it all.

Petals on the wind—
even the sky seems to smile
at their gentle fall.

Mud clings to my boots,
but the path is full of birds—
and that's enough now.

A branch once bare bends,
cradling buds like secrets
it's ready to share.

The snow finally
melts into a song of streams—
we drink and forget.

You open the blinds—
and just like that, sunlight spills
where silence once slept.

A child runs through grass,
their laughter planting flowers
with each step they take.

Rain taps on the roof—
not lonely, but full of hope,
a rhythm of green.

Warm wind through the trees,
and the world exhales slowly
as if it just woke.

Cherry trees explode—
a sudden, reckless beauty
before it is gone.

The first bee appears,
uncertain, but not afraid—
I take that lesson.

The earth smells like rain,
and somewhere beneath the mud
new roots are whispering.

Soft green everywhere—
as if the world remembered
how to be gentle.

A sparrow returns,
nesting in the same old eave—
we both needed this.

Winds tug at the sheets,
and you laugh as they escape—
spring is mischievous.

The sun finds my face
through a gap in the branches—
a brief, golden touch.

Snowdrops brave the cold,
as if to say, It's time now—
you can start again.

Windows open wide,
letting in bees, dust, and dreams
we forgot we had.

The cat naps outside,
belly up to the warm breeze—
even stillness grows.

Dandelions bloom—
tiny suns beneath my feet,
cheerful and defiant.

You hand me one bud,
not yet open, but promised—
a whole season there.

Rain taps on the leaves,
a gentle and steady voice
saying, You are safe.

Umbrellas bloom bright
against a sky full of sighs—
even clouds let go.

Mud stains my hemline,
but I keep walking, smiling—
spring rain hides my tears.

Puddles on the path—
reflections that ripple out
like thoughts not yet said.

The rain finds the roof,
and every drop becomes song
we didn't expect.

Shoots rise from the ground,
drenched and reaching for the light—
as if they believe.

We shared one jacket—
shoulders soaked, hands intertwined,
forgetting the chill.

Rain clings to the buds,
weighing them just for a breath
before setting free.

A storm came softly—
no thunder, no sharp lightning—
just a hush, and green.

The scent after rain—
not just earth, but forgiveness,
as if time resets.

Cicadas cry loud—
as if summer itself burns
just to be noticed.

The fan turns slowly,
moving nothing but the heat
and old, quiet thoughts.

Sunlight through the glass—
even shadows seem to sweat
in the heavy air.

Ice melts in my cup,
sweet tea bleeding into gold—
time slows with each sip.

Bare feet in the grass,
the scent of cut lawns rising—
I forget to speak.

A lake at high noon—
every ripple blinding bright,
every breath a gift.

The hammock sways slow,
trees humming their greenest tune
with each sleepy breeze.

A moth at the screen,
drawn to something it can't reach—
aren't we all like that?

Night sticks to the skin,
and fireflies float like wishes
that never quite land.

You laugh through the haze,
and suddenly summer feels
like it might stay long.

Backpacks on the floor,
we chase maps and open roads
like the breeze itself.

Canoes on the lake—
each paddle stroke pulling us
deeper into now.

Sunburned and laughing,
we run through the wild grasses
with no plan at all.

Tents in the still dusk,
stories shared by flashlight glow—
every laugh a spark.

High above the cliffs,
the wind dares us not to leap—
but still, we look down.

Sticky with peach juice,
you jump into the river—
summer tastes like this.

We got lost again,
but the stars came out for us—
even they wander.

Bare wheels on warm roads,
a playlist and empty time—
every turn a choice.

A trail through the pines,
just wide enough for wonder
and maybe your hand.

We slept in the sand,
woke to gulls and golden light—
no one knew our names.

The cicadas stop—
and just like that, the silence
feels heavier now.

Leaves begin to turn,
as if the trees remembered
how to let things go.

Your towel still damp,
sand clinging like memories—
the beach almost bare.

The last fireflies blink,
as if unsure where to go
when no one is left.

Ice cream trucks grow rare,
their songs fading down the streets
no one waits along.

You pack up the tent,
but leave behind one long laugh—
caught between the trees.

The sun sets sooner,
slinking off without a word—
too tired to stay.

A suitcase half-zipped,
tan lines fading into skin—
summer doesn't last.

Shirtsleeves at the store,
sweaters creeping toward the front—
a quiet warning.

We talk less these days,
as if the heat once held us
closer than we knew.

School bells in the air,
even for those not going—
change calls anyway.

A single cricket
sings where thousands used to hum—
even joy must rest.

The pier stands empty,
sunset painting its edges
with slow goodbyes.

We don't say it's done—
just stretch the golden hours
until they all fade.

Autumn waits nearby,
but still—one last bare sunset
between you and me.

Leaves drift through the air,
red and gold confessions made
without saying much.

The wind starts to speak,
not in warmth, but in warnings—
wrap your heart in wool.

Pumpkins on doorsteps,
their orange laughter glowing
through the cooling dusk.

A crow on a branch—
black against the breaking sky,
quiet, but watching.

Mugs of something warm,
fingers curled like fallen leaves—
we learn how to hold.

The forest exhales,
breathing fire before the snow—
a beautiful end.

Apple-sweetened air,
and the soft crunch underfoot—
walking through a song.

The sun lingers low,
spilling gold across the fields
like it knows it's time.

A scarf on the chair,
a window cracked just enough
for the season's sigh.

Trees strip down to truth,
no shame in their bareness now—
teaching me the same.

Candlelight flickers,
and the pages of old books
turn slower these days.

The sky forgets blue,
paints in muted, tender shades—
colors of goodbye.

Footsteps echo more,
as if the world's growing still
to listen to leaves.

Bonfires crackle sharp—
not to warm, but to remind
what light used to be.

We meet in sweaters,
and though we both say hello,
it already feels like end.

Chill beneath my coat—
even the wind has stories
it won't say out loud.

Lanterns line the path,
glowing like gentle echoes
of a summer gone.

Leaves crunch underfoot,
each step a soft reminder
of what once was green.

Morning fog clings tight,
as if trying to keep us
from what's slipping past.

A porch swing sways slow,
not from use, but memory—
just enough to creak.

The moon rises pale,
wading through October mist
like a silent thought.

Hands in deeper sleeves—
we talk of nothing at all,
but mean everything.

Cornfields lean and bend,
tired from holding the sun
for one more season.

Firewood stacked with care—
a ritual of quiet
that smells like safety.

Ghosts of laughter fade
at the edges of the fair—
cotton candy cold.

You bring in the plants,
whispering to each one soft
as if they'll miss light.

The air tastes like smoke,
and something we never said
lingers on our tongues.

A jacket half-zipped—
still hoping for warm enough,
still bracing for less.

Children chase the wind,
kites tangled in golden trees—
a lesson in joy.

Across the still pond,
leaves land like folded letters
sent from another time.

Pumpkins on the porch
flicker with mischievous grins—
the night wakes laughing.

Footsteps on dry leaves—
children in glowing costumes
hunt shadows for sweets.

Candle wax runs slow,
spilling spells across the floor
in soft, orange light.

A howl in the dark—
not a wolf, but a small child
wearing teeth and joy.

Fake webs on the fence,
but one strand trembles too real—
I don't check again.

Ghosts float down the street—
bedsheets, giggles, and flashlights
under moonlit masks.

The air smells like spice,
burned sugar, and something else—
just beneath the sweet.

A plastic vampire
offers me a plastic grin—
we both pretend well.

Jack-o'-lantern eyes
watch the world with crooked light,
flames flickering truths.

Doorbells ring again—
bags open like hungry mouths,
Trick or treat! they sing.

The trees bend closer,
as if they, too, want to hear
what the spirits say.

Laughter down the lane,
mixed with rustling, running feet—
no one walks alone.

Old costumes pulled out,
still holding the scent of dust
and some leftover dreams.

Fog rolls in too fast,
draping over lawn displays—
making them feel real.

A witch casts a spell—
two glow sticks, a candy bar,
and a memory.

Lanterns line the walk,
each flame a tiny portal
to some other world.

A broom on the porch—
no one asks who rode it here,
but the cat stays close.

Costumes at sunrise—
wrinkled capes and plastic fangs
left like dreams half-spent.

Moonlight on the road,
and for once, we walk slower—
savoring the thrill.

A giggle, then hush—
someone saw something move
where no one had been.

Candy in my hands,
too much to eat, yet I try—
it tastes like freedom.

Masks hide every face,
but even under makeup,
we know who is who.

A scarecrow leans in,
as if it has something to
say—then thinks better.

Fake blood on the steps—
every year we paint the same
wounds we've come to love.

The skeleton laughs,
plastic bones clattering loud
in the autumn breeze.

Porch lights blink and fade,
and in the hush between knocks,
we feel we're not lone.

Pumpkin seeds roasted,
still warm in the kitchen bowl—
a spell of their own.

Eyes peer from the bush—
maybe kids, maybe not kids.
You decide. Or don't.

A cape in the wind,
flapping like a startled bat—
then gone down the street.

We whisper ghost tales,
not caring if they are true—
it's better that way.

Snow falls without sound,
as if the world is holding
its breath for a star.

Pine scent in the air,
gifts wrapped in soft paper dreams—
the hush before joy.

Lights along the eaves,
twinkling like tiny wishes
that forgot to fade.

A mug in both hands,
steam rising like memories—
spiced, sweet, and distant.

Stockings by the fire,
as if they believe again
just for one more year.

Cold glass on my cheek—
outside, the world is silent,
waiting to be known.

Midnight carols drift,
voices threading through the snow
like old lullabies.

The tree glows softly—
even the ornaments seem
to breathe in the light.

Footsteps on the stairs,
hearts thudding like sleigh bells do
when no one should hear.

Paper angels sway,
hung by hands now grown older—
the tape still holds strong.

Cracked cookies and crumbs—
not perfect, but still offered
with joy unspoken.

The fire burns low,
but no one gets up to move—
every silence full.

Snowflakes on your coat,
melting like secret wishes
you didn't say loud.

The calendar waits,
its last page folded gently—
still, we light the tree.

Hands reach for my own—
and suddenly, Christmas feels
like it always did.

The tree stands in light,
wrapped in gold and old stories
we still believe in.

Carols through the door—
a voice off-key, still singing
like it means the world.

Snow dusts the mailbox,
and the cards inside whisper
names we miss too much.

Ribbon curls like smoke
around the unopened gift—
some things feel too big.

The wreath on the door
smells of pine and promises—
we step through with care.

A candle half-burned
sits beside the quiet plate—
he said he'd be late.

You hand me cocoa,
our fingers brush, and for once,
no one needs to speak.

Cracks in the old bulbs,
but we hang them anyway—
they still hold their light.

The attic creaks loud,
as if the stored decorations
can't wait to return.

Laughter from the den,
and even the coldest hearts
soften at the sound.

Mittens on the sill—
forgotten in all the joy
of running outside.

The cat climbs the tree,
batting stars from their branches—
chaos made lovely.

Wrapping paper strewn,
echoes of the morning still
rustle through the floor.

One light flickers out,
but we leave it as it is—
flaws feel welcome here.

Snow falls once again,
and with it, something softer
settles in my chest.

Clock hands almost meet—
we count down with breath held tight,
hoping this one sticks.

Champagne in our hands,
and something like forgiveness
bubbles at the rim.

Fireworks bloom bright,
writing promises in smoke
that drift toward silence.

You whisper New Start—
as if the calendar page
can erase the past.

Sparklers in our grip,
we trace names into the dark—
then let them vanish.

A kiss after twelve—
not magic, but close enough
for a moment's grace.

The streets fill with sound—
but somewhere deep in the noise,
someone makes a wish.

I write resolutions
with the same trembling hope as
the ones I forgot.

Lanterns in the sky—
we send them up carefully,
filled with almosts.

A room full of light,
glitter clinging to our sleeves—
tomorrow can wait.

Midnight through the blinds—
quiet cheers in the distance,
and one held breath here.

Confetti like snow—
promises we'll laugh about
when the year runs thin.

The old year exhales,
a long sigh across the earth—
the new one listens.

You text me at twelve—
two words, just Still Here—and yet,
it says everything.

We toast to the dawn,
to all that hasn't happened—
and might, if we try.

New year, fresh sunrise,
hope leaps in every heartbeat,
joy lights every step.

Bright spark at midnight,
laughter and dreams take their flight,
warmth fills the cool night.

Cheers in every smile,
our wishes glow like starlight,
paths open to us.

Glitter in the air,
hopes soaring on joyful winds,
hearts shine with promise.

New chapters await,
a canvas brushed with pure gold,
dreams dance into life.

Blessings all around,
whispers of fortune and light,
spirits rise as one.

Hearts aglow with hope,
resolutions softly bloom,
joy awakens all.

A toast to the new,
spirits lifted in delight,
smiles brighten our way.

Golden bells are ringing,
carrying our joyful vows,
sunrise in our souls.

Fireworks in our eyes,
dreams sparkling in the night sky,
unity inspires.

Dawn of endless bliss,
optimism fills the new day,
love guides every breath.

New paths bright and clear,
each moment sings with promise,
life unfolds in light.

Fresh beginnings call,
together we step into hope,
joy in every beat.

Radiant and bold,
we chase dreams and greet the morn,
heart and hope align.

New year, pure promise,
our smiles kindle uncharted days,
joy in every breath.

A fresh page turns slow—
even the sun seems eager
to begin again.

Laughter after twelve,
sparks dancing in the night sky—
the future feels light.

We hold hands and breathe,
not fearing what comes next now—
just glad to be here.

A toast to the stars—
we drink to wild, open roads
and full-hearted steps.

New slippers, warm tea—
even quiet beginnings
can change everything.

The house still asleep,
but my heart is wide awake
and already new.

We set goals and laugh—
not because they won't happen,
but because they might.

Fireworks still fall,
and for a breathless moment,
it all feels so clear.

Confetti like seeds—
planting joy across the floor
one bright color each.

Morning stretches wide,
welcoming the world again
without hesitation.

The calendar waits—
blank and bursting with promise,
a gift we unwrap.

Your eyes say let's try
before the words even come—
hope speaks with silence.

Music in the streets,
every step a small dance step—
a soft revolution.

A single sunrise—
and suddenly the whole world
feels lighter again.

We say Happy Year!
like it's a spell we believe—
and somehow, it works.

A song on the wind—
and just like that, I'm thirteen,
barefoot in the grass.

Your coat in the hall—
still hanging like you might come
back to grab one thing.

The photo is bent,
but your smile folds gently still—
time could not erase.

Old perfume lingers
on the scarf you left behind—
a ghost I still wear.

The lake we once swam
is smaller than I recall—
but not in my mind.

Your handwriting fades,
but I still trace every line
with remembering.

Dust on the piano,
but each key knows the pieces
we played in silence.

Laughter from next door—
for a moment, I believed
you were home again.

I open the book,
just to find the pressed flower
you forgot you gave.

The swing creaks alone—
I push it once, and it moves
like you never left.

We spoke in whispers,
not to hide, but to keep time
from stealing our words.

I keep the old key,
though the door it once belonged
to is long replaced.

Rain against the roof—
every drop sounds like a year
I'm still holding close.

You're not in the room,
but something about the light
feels like you arrived.

Memory is soft—
it doesn't knock or announce,
it just takes its seat.

Fireflies in jars—
we swore they were tiny stars
we could keep forever.

Grass stains on our knees,
and laughter echoing through
the long, endless dusk.

That old tire swing swayed
like it knew every secret
we never could say.

Crayons in a box—
some broken, some barely used—
still smelled like wonder.

Ice cream on my chin,
melted faster than I could
finish my story.

Grandpa's radio
crackled out the morning news
and smelled like coffee.

The fort made of sheets
was our kingdom, ruled by light
from a flashlight throne.

Training wheels off slow—
you ran beside me until
you let go, smiling.

Skipping school to play—
the guilt tasted like freedom
and something like sun.

The bell rang too soon,
but I stayed behind to draw
one more dragon's wing.

The rain on the roof
felt louder back in those days,
and somehow more kind.

We whispered at night,
thinking the dark couldn't hear—
our dreams made it real.

Mom called from the porch,
and the day folded gently
into warm lamplight.

Pockets full of rocks,
leaves, and all the magic things
we were sure mattered.

In that faded frame,
you hold my hand, both of us
unaware of time.

First day, new backpack—
too big for my small shoulders,
but I stood taller.

The mirror changed me
before I even noticed—
my eyes stayed the same.

Voices cracked with fear,
and laughter we didn't mean—
both growing pains, both.

A locker slammed shut,
and with it, all the secrets
we pretended worked.

You said don't look back—
and so we ran even though
we wanted to turn.

The world seemed too big,
but we still made tiny maps
in notebooks and hearts.

My hands used to shake
when I had to speak aloud—
they don't anymore.

We carved our names in
trees that no longer stand now—
but I still recall.

Tears came without cause,
and sometimes so did the joy—
both arrived like rain.

That first real heartbreak
was not the end of the world—
but it sure felt close.

The road out of town
never felt as far away
as the one back in.

We outgrew our dreams,
but kept the scraps in our drawers—
just in case they fit.

Late summer bonfires,
and that feeling we were more
than just temporary.

I wore your old coat—
too big, but it held stories
I wasn't done with.

Growing up was this—
learning how to hold on tight
and still let things go.

Names slip through my hands
like sand I thought I had held—
they don't answer now.

You smile patiently,
as if I'm a song you knew
but can't quite recall.

Photos on the wall—
faces I should recognize
blur into color.

The kettle still hums,
but I can't remember why
I walked to the stove.

A drawer half-open,
full of letters I once wrote
to someone like me.

You say Do you know?—
I nod, but the truth is lost
somewhere in the fog.

The calendar waits,
but each day arrives without
meaning or hello.

The mirror forgets
what I looked like yesterday—
and so do I now.

Your name on my lips—
a sound I once held tightly
now just drifts like smoke.

They bring me tulips,
and I thank them like I know
why that means something.

The hallway feels long,
full of doors I used to know
how to open wide.

I laugh at a joke,
then forget who told it to
and why it still hurts.

The clock ticks gently—
but I am unmoored from time,
a boat without rope.

Sometimes, I remember—
brief and bright like lightning flash,
then the dark returns.

You hold both my hands,
and though I don't know your name,
I know that it's love.

You ask who I am—
I smile and say just someone
who's glad to see you.

Your hands fold again,
as if they're holding something
you no longer name.

I tell you the tale
of how we first met—again—
and you laugh anew.

The spoon shakes slightly,
so I steady it with mine—
we do this slowly.

You hum half a tune,
and I hum the rest with you—
that much still remains.

We walk the same path,
and though you forget the way,
you still trust my steps.

You call me mother—
and though I am not, I say
yes, my love, I'm here.

I answer your fears
with the same soft words each time—
it matters to you.

The nurse says your name,
but it floats right past your eyes—
still, I say it too.

Your stories unravel,
but I gather every thread
like it's made of gold.

I write your name down
on sticky notes by the door—
tiny lifelines there.

Some days you are clear—
a sunbeam through heavy clouds—
and I don't breathe deep.

You hold my old scarf
and say it feels like someone
who loved you so much.

The clock strikes again,
but here, time does not pass right—
it only circles.

You sleep in my arms,
and though you don't say my name,
you hold me like home.

Clouds kiss the peak slow—
as if the sky itself bowed
to something so old.

Stone beneath my feet,
and silence so wide it feels
like a kind of truth.

The path narrows here,
but the wind keeps urging me—
it has no fear left.

Snow rests on the cliffs,
not heavy, just respectful—
like hands in still prayer.

Mountains do not speak,
but I leave with answers I
never came to find.

Fog climbs through the trees,
braiding with the early light—
the whole world exhales.

A hawk cuts the sky,
smaller than the peak below—
still it dares to soar.

Each echo returns,
carrying more than my voice—
this place remembers.

My breath meets the cold,
and for one bright, burning step,
I am part of it.

Rocks worn smooth by time—
they don't speak of the storms passed,
they just keep standing.

I look down and see
miles of moments left behind—
and feel taller now.

A cabin, half-hid,
smoke curling like a secret
the mountain will keep.

No signal, no sound—
only wind and steady stone
telling me to stay.

You reached for my hand
at the cliff's edge, not in fear,
but to share the view.

Stars above, rock below—
this is the in-between place
where the soul grows still.

At dawn, the peaks glow—
as if the sun remembers
where it rose from first.

A goat on the ledge—
sure-footed where I would fall,
teaching balance well.

The climb takes my breath,
but not from the height alone—
it's the view, the hush.

Clouds gather and pass,
touching the stone like old friends
with nothing to prove.

The mountain holds snow
long after the storms have gone—
some things stay colder.

Cairns mark the worn path—
signs left by those who once stood
where I now am still.

Beneath these tall pines,
even my loudest thoughts fade
into the cool hush.

A stream breaks the rock,
not with force but patience—and
there is wisdom there.

Long shadows at dusk—
the mountain tucks in the light
like a mother would.

Ravens circle high,
drawing spirals in the sky
no hand ever could.

You asked what I saw—
but I could not speak it then,
only breathe it in.

From this quiet height,
the world seems both far away
and entirely mine.

An old trail splits here,
faded signs, and yet I know
which way calls my name.

I leave no footprints—
the snow takes them as a gift
and keeps them softly.

The mountain won't move,
but it changes me each time—
without saying how.

Moss softens each step—
as if the forest prefers
to keep all things hushed.

Sunlight through the leaves
paints the path in shifting gold—
the ground breathes with light.

A deer lifts its head—
I stop mid-step, heart and breath
held like sacred things.

Roots rise from the ground,
reminding me to slow down
and walk like I care.

Birdsong everywhere—
a thousand small conversations
I don't understand.

A trail lost in ferns—
maybe it never existed,
or maybe I strayed.

Rain drips from the pines,
each drop a tiny blessing
for whatever comes.

The trees do not move,
but they listen all the same
to what we don't say.

Sap clings to my hands—
a gift I didn't ask for,
but carry with pride.

A fox crosses near,
eyes meeting mine just briefly—
both of us alone.

Fallen logs decay,
yet green things grow from the dark—
nothing is wasted.

The wind knows my name,
but speaks it so softly that
I almost forget.

In the forest's heart,
even time dares not hurry—
it walks, as I do.

Mushrooms at my feet,
as if the earth was laughing
in tiny whispers.

I left something here—
not lost, just given freely
to the breathing woods.

The trees do not sleep—
they just stand in deeper thought
when the moonlight comes.

A branch creaks, then stops—
not wind, not animal—just
something watching back.

Stars between the pines—
fragments of the sky caught in
branches like secrets.

A fox slips through dark,
its eyes glowing for a breath—
then the night swallows.

The forest exhales,
and in that long, smoky breath
I forget my name.

Owls call through the trees—
not to scare, but to remind
we're never alone.

My footsteps go still,
as if even the earth says
this place is sacred.

Fireflies drift slowly,
small lanterns in tangled leaves—
the stars walk with me.

The path disappears—
night takes it with gentle hands,
leaving only sound.

Frog song in the dark,
a lullaby for shadows
and those who still roam.

Moonlight on the moss—
it glows like a memory
I almost recall.

I speak, and it falls—
my voice eaten by the trees,
as if they were full.

A cold wind drifts through,
carrying not fear, but awe—
a weightless silence.

Eyes blink in the dark—
not danger, but curiosity
mirroring my own.

The forest at night
does not ask where you have been—
it just lets you be.

Roots hum with old songs—
not in words, but in the hush
between heartbeats. Listen.

A stag made of stars
steps through the silver-barked trees—
the moon holds its breath.

Leaves whisper your name,
but it's not the one you knew—
the forest renamed you.

Lanterns in the mist—
but no path beneath your feet,
just the pull of trust.

Moss glows underfoot,
as if the ground remembers
how to dream in light.

A tree opens wide,
not with creak or cry, but calm—
as if it has teeth.

Foxes walk upright,
tipping hats of falling leaves—
they nod, then vanish.

The air tastes like spells—
not cast by hands, but spoken
by the breath of trees.

A stone ring half-sunk—
someone danced here once, and still
the soil remembers.

Time stumbles here, lost—
seasons blur, and you forget
which sky you came from.

You drink from the stream,
and for one soft, shining hour
every wound is gone.

The forest shifts shape—
paths re-twist, branches rearrange—
only the brave smile.

Wind brings distant bells,
but no tower stands nearby—
only roots, and hush.

Your shadow walks off,
unwilling to follow you
where the myths begin.

When you leave the wood,
the trees sigh—and something stays
behind in your place.

The river hums low—
a lullaby for the stones
it's worn smooth with time.

Water rushes past,
but never forgets the curve
of where it has been.

I dip in my hand—
it takes nothing, gives me peace,
and keeps on moving.

A heron stands still—
a single note in the song
of endless motion.

Mist above the stream—
the morning hasn't decided
if it will be clear.

Leaves ride the current,
tiny boats with no captain—
and yet they still go.

Beneath all the sound,
the river holds its own thoughts,
never quite revealed.

Rain joins with a splash,
taken in without question—
every drop belongs.

Children at the edge
throw stones like small confessions—
the river forgives.

I follow its path,
not to find where it ends, but
to lose where I am.

The river grows thin,
then wide again—reminding
change is never wrong.

Reflections distort—
I see myself in the flow,
but not as I was.

A fallen branch drifts,
and though it floats aimlessly,
it still reaches sea.

Even in winter,
a quiet trickle persists—
a promise of spring.

Moonlight on the waves—
the river carries silver
like it knows its worth.

Nets tossed at first light—
each ripple holds the hunger
of another day.

Bare feet on wet wood,
a fisherman hums softly
while the world wakes slow.

The boat rocks gently—
child asleep on bundled nets,
cradled by the flow.

A woman scrubs cloth,
songs of her mother rising
with the splash and soap.

Fish sizzle in oil,
the river's gift turned to warmth
on a clay hearth fire.

Poles rest by the door,
carved smooth by the hands and years
of waiting on tides.

Smoke curls from the roof—
rice steamed as the boat drifts back
with enough for all.

A boy casts his line,
dreaming not of the catch, but
what it will bring home.

Oars echo at dusk,
two sisters ferrying goods
to the distant shore.

Paint peels from the hull,
but still the boat finds its way—
a veteran's grace.

Muddy hands plant rice
beside the singing river—
life drawn from the flow.

A weathered old man
mends the net by moonlight's edge—
every knot a tale.

Baskets brim with reeds,
woven through with morning mist
and quiet purpose.

Children race the tide,
laughing in the water's pull—
already learning.

When the flood comes near,
we lift stories, not just walls—
the river knows all.

Houses on stilts rise—
cradled by the breathing tide
like lullabies sung.

Boats tied side by side,
the dock becomes a small street
floating with chatter.

Roosters crow at dawn,
and smoke curls from reed rooftops—
the river stirs too.

Children leap from planks,
splashing into warm brown waves—
laughter sails downstream.

A temple bell rings,
and even the drifting boats
pause to listen in.

Fish strung out to dry,
fluttering like prayer flags
against the shoreline.

The shop floats gently,
selling fruit from boat to boat—
commerce on the breeze.

Old women gossip
while weaving nets in the shade—
they know every tide.

Candles in the dusk—
small boats drift with offerings
past eyes full of hope.

Flood marks on the post,
scratched by years and measured loss—
still, the roofs hold strong.

Children chase the rain,
dancing barefoot through puddles
that mirror the sky.

A boy counts the boats,
names each one like a brother
he's grown up beside.

Drums echo at night—
a wedding floats past the reeds
in a trail of song.

The midwife arrives
by canoe, steady and sure—
life comes with the tide.

From one shore to next,
the river carries voices—
no fences can hold.

Waves erase my steps—
the sea takes what it's given
without looking back.

Salt clings to my skin,
a reminder I belong
to something deeper.

Seagulls cry above,
not lost, just carried forward
on the wind's old song.

A shell at my feet—
its spiral holds the silence
of a thousand tides.

The horizon bends,
and I wonder what begins
just beyond my reach.

Fishermen set sail,
their eyes fixed on morning light—
faith rides every wave.

The ocean at dusk—
colors too wide to be named
spill across the foam.

Storm clouds gather fast,
but still the gulls glide steady—
no fear in their wings.

Ships blink in the dark,
lanterns hung on memory—
hoping for safe shore.

I whisper your name,
but the ocean does not change—
it already knows.

The wind tastes of salt,
and something old, half-forgotten,
that still remembers.

Tide pools catch the stars,
holding constellations close
just until they fade.

Sailboats on the blue—
tiny prayers drifting out
with no guarantee.

Beneath all the waves,
so much life unseen, unmoved—
and yet, always there.

The sea and I sit,
both too wide to explain, yet
neither one alone.

A school of silver
moves as one body of light—
the sea holds its breath.

Octopus in shade,
shifting colors like secrets
it never reveals.

Coral branches sway,
homes built from patient silence
and a thousand lives.

A whale sings alone,
and the song carries farther
than any of us.

Turtles drift like dreams,
unchanged by the world above—
ancient and content.

Tiny crabs scuttle
sideways across wet footprints—
no path, only tide.

Jellyfish pulse bright—
silent lanterns of the deep,
dancing with the dark.

Seahorses curl close,
riding slow waves through the reeds—
tender in the drift.

Sharks glide through the dusk,
not cruel, not kind, only still—
all hunger and grace.

Starfish on the rocks—
a quiet kind of waiting
until the sea calls.

Dolphins break the waves,
joy written in every leap—
a language of light.

An eel in the dark
flickers like a question mark—
you'll never answer.

Barnacles hold fast,
no matter how hard the tide
pulls them toward change.

A ray sweeps the sand,
as if brushing old secrets
underneath the floor.

Deep beneath it all,
eyes glow where no light should reach—
the sea still sees you.

Stars blink into life—
a language too old for sound,
too vast for questions.

A comet drifts by,
its tail a fleeting whisper
no one gets to keep.

Planets spin in dark,
each alone, but never lost—
orbits like old vows.

In the astronaut's
helmet glass, a distant moon—
home, and not quite home.

Light from ancient stars
falls across my open hand—
time folded in fire.

Black holes hold their breath,
silent mouths that do not speak,
only pull and pull.

Dust floats in the void—
future worlds not yet written,
but waiting their turn.

Martian soil is red,
but the silence here is white—
sharp as morning frost.

The rover stands still,
sending home its last message—
a machine grown old.

We launch one more craft,
knowing it won't return, but
something of us will.

Galaxies unwind
like the threads of old stories—
we read from afar.

A ring of Saturn
shimmers like a frozen song—
no singer, no end.

Our signals reach out,
soft and full of hope, like hands
in an endless dark.

The moon wears no face,
but I still wave up to it—
a child's old habit.

Even out past light,
some part of us dares to dream—
and calls that starlight.
